trans-unit.source: Toutes les applications qui communiquent avec les ressources et les services à distance doivent être sensibles aux pannes passagères.

trans-unit.source: C'est particulièrement le cas pour les applications qui s'exécutent dans le nuage, où la nature de l'environnement et de la connectivité sur Internet signifie que ces types d'erreurs sont susceptibles d'être rencontrées le plus souvent.

trans-unit.source: Anomalies transitoires comprennent la perte momentanée de la connectivité réseau aux services et composants, l'indisponibilité temporaire d'un service, ou les délais d'attente qui se posent lorsqu'un service est occupé.

trans-unit.source: Hébergement Cloud, y compris les systèmes de cloud privé, peut offrir une plus grande disponibilité globale en utilisant les ressources partagées, redondance, basculement automatique, et les nœuds de calcul d'allocation dynamique des ressources à travers un grand nombre de produits de base.

trans-unit.source: Beaucoup de ressources dans un environnement de Cloud Computing est partagées, et accès à ces ressources est soumis à limitation afin de protéger la ressource.

trans-unit.target: La limitation contribue à maintenir la qualité du service pour les voisins et les autres locataires à l'aide de la ressource partagée.

trans-unit.target: Il y a souvent plusieurs composants matériels, y compris l'infrastructure de réseau tels que les routeurs et les équilibreurs de charge, entre l'application et les ressources et les services qu'il utilise.

trans-unit.source: L'application doit être capable de détecter les failles lorsqu'ils se produisent et déterminer si ces défauts sont susceptibles d'être transitoire, plus durable, ou est des échecs de connexion.
trans-unit.target: L'application doit être capable de détecter les failles lorsqu'ils se produisent et déterminer si ces défauts sont susceptibles d'être transitoire, plus durable, ou est des échecs de connexion.

trans-unit.target: Différentes ressources sont susceptibles de retourner des réponses différentes lorsque survient une panne, et ces réponses peuvent également varier selon le contexte de l'opération ; par exemple, la réponse d'erreur lors de la lecture de stockage peut être différente de la réponse d'erreur lors de l'écriture au stockage.

trans-unit.source: Lignes directrices générales
trans-unit.target: Lignes directrices générales

trans-unit.source: Les lignes directrices suivantes vous aideront à concevoir un défaut transitoire approprié remise mécanisme pour vos applications :
trans-unit.target: Les lignes directrices suivantes vous aideront à concevoir un défaut transitoire approprié remise mécanisme pour vos applications :

trans-unit.source: Determine if there is a built-in retry mechanism:
trans-unit.target: Determine if there is a built-in retry mechanism:

trans-unit.source: Many services provide an SDK or client library that contains a transient fault handling mechanism.
trans-unit.target: Many services provide an SDK or client library that contains a transient fault handling mechanism.

trans-unit.source: The retry policy it uses is typically tailored to the nature and requirements of the target service.
trans-unit.target: The retry policy it uses is typically tailored to the nature and requirements of the target service.

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, REST interfaces for services may return information that is useful in determining whether a retry is appropriate, and how long to wait before the next retry attempt.
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, REST interfaces for services may return information that is useful in determining whether a retry is appropriate, and how long to wait before the next retry attempt.

trans-unit.source: Use the built-in retry mechanism where one is available unless you have specific and well-understood requirements that mean a different retry behavior is more appropriate.
trans-unit.target: Use the built-in retry mechanism where one is available unless you have specific and well-understood requirements that mean a different retry behavior is more appropriate.

trans-unit.source: Determine if the operation is suitable for retrying:
trans-unit.target: Determine if the operation is suitable for retrying:

trans-unit.source: You should only retry operations where the faults are transient (typically indicated by the nature of the error), and if there is at least some likelihood that the operation will succeed when reattempted.
trans-unit.target: You should only retry operations where the faults are transient (typically indicated by the nature of the error), and if there is at least some likelihood that the operation will succeed when reattempted.

trans-unit.source: There is no point in reattempting operations that indicate an invalid operation such as a database update to an item that does not exist, or requests to a service or resource that has suffered a fatal error
trans-unit.target: There is no point in reattempting operations that indicate an invalid operation such as a database update to an item that does not exist, or requests to a service or resource that has suffered a fatal error

trans-unit.source: In general, you should implement retries only where the full impact of this can be determined, and the conditions are well understood and can be validated.
trans-unit.target: In general, you should implement retries only where the full impact of this can be determined, and the conditions are well understood and can be validated.

trans-unit.source: If not, leave it to the calling code to implement retries.
trans-unit.target: If not, leave it to the calling code to implement retries.

trans-unit.source: Remember that the errors returned from resources and services outside your control may evolve over time, and you may need to revisit your transient fault detection logic.
trans-unit.target: Remember that the errors returned from resources and services outside your control may evolve over time, and you may need to revisit your transient fault detection logic.

trans-unit.source: When you create services or components, consider implementing error codes and messages that will help clients determine whether they should retry failed operations.
trans-unit.target: When you create services or components, consider implementing error codes and messages that will help clients determine whether they should retry failed operations.

trans-unit.source: In particular, indicate if the client should retry the operation (perhaps by returning an isTransient value) and suggest a suitable delay before the next retry attempt.
trans-unit.target: In particular, indicate if the client should retry the operation (perhaps by returning an isTransient value) and suggest a suitable delay before the next retry attempt.

trans-unit.source: If you build a web service, consider returning custom errors defined within your service contracts.
trans-unit.target: If you build a web service, consider returning custom errors defined within your service contracts.

trans-unit.source: Even though generic clients may not be able to read these, they will be useful when building custom clients.
trans-unit.target: Even though generic clients may not be able to read these, they will be useful when building custom clients.

trans-unit.source: Determine an appropriate retry count and interval:
trans-unit.target: Determine an appropriate retry count and interval:

trans-unit.source: It is vital to optimize the retry count and the interval to the type of use case.
trans-unit.target: It is vital to optimize the retry count and the interval to the type of use case.

trans-unit.source: If you do not retry a sufficient number of times, the application will be unable to complete the operation and is likely to experience a failure.
trans-unit.target: If you do not retry a sufficient number of times, the application will be unable to complete the operation and is likely to experience a failure.

trans-unit.source: If you retry too many times, or with too short an interval between tries, the application can potentially hold resources such as threads, connections, and memory for long periods, which will adversely affect the health of the application.
trans-unit.target: If you retry too many times, or with too short an interval between tries, the application can potentially hold resources such as threads, connections, and memory for long periods, which will adversely affect the health of the application.

trans-unit.source: The appropriate values for the time interval and the number of retry attempts depend on the type of operation being attempted.
trans-unit.target: The appropriate values for the time interval and the number of retry attempts depend on the type of operation being attempted.

trans-unit.source: For example, if the operation is part of a user interaction, the interval should be short and only a few retries attempted to avoid making users wait for a response (which holds open connections and can reduce availability for other users).
trans-unit.target: For example, if the operation is part of a user interaction, the interval should be short and only a few retries attempted to avoid making users wait for a response (which holds open connections and can reduce availability for other users).

trans-unit.source: If the operation is part of a long running or critical workflow, where cancelling and restarting the process is expensive or time-consuming, it is appropriate to wait longer between attempts and retry more times.
trans-unit.target: If the operation is part of a long running or critical workflow, where cancelling and restarting the process is expensive or time-consuming, it is appropriate to wait longer between attempts and retry more times.

trans-unit.source: Determining the appropriate intervals between retries is the most difficult part of designing a successful strategy.
trans-unit.target: Determining the appropriate intervals between retries is the most difficult part of designing a successful strategy.

trans-unit.source: Typical strategies use the following types of retry interval:
trans-unit.target: Typical strategies use the following types of retry interval:

trans-unit.source: Exponential back-off.
trans-unit.target: Exponential back-off.

trans-unit.source: The application waits a short time before the first retry, and then exponentially increasing times between each subsequent retry.
trans-unit.target: The application waits a short time before the first retry, and then exponentially increasing times between each subsequent retry.

trans-unit.source: For example, it may retry the operation after 3 seconds, 12 seconds, 30 seconds, and so on.
trans-unit.target: For example, it may retry the operation after 3 seconds, 12 seconds, 30 seconds, and so on.

trans-unit.source: Incremental intervals.
trans-unit.target: Incremental intervals.

trans-unit.source: The application waits a short time before the first retry, and then incrementally increasing times between each subsequent retry.
trans-unit.target: The application waits a short time before the first retry, and then incrementally increasing times between each subsequent retry.

trans-unit.source: For example, it may retry the operation after 3 seconds, 7 seconds, 13 seconds, and so on.
trans-unit.target: For example, it may retry the operation after 3 seconds, 7 seconds, 13 seconds, and so on.

trans-unit.source: Regular intervals.
trans-unit.target: Regular intervals.

trans-unit.source: The application waits for the same period of time between each attempt.
trans-unit.target: The application waits for the same period of time between each attempt.

trans-unit.source: For example, it may retry the operation every 3 seconds.
trans-unit.target: For example, it may retry the operation every 3 seconds.

trans-unit.source: Immediate retry.
trans-unit.target: Immediate retry.

trans-unit.source: Sometimes a transient fault is extremely short, perhaps caused by an event such as a network packet collision or a spike in a hardware component.
trans-unit.target: Sometimes a transient fault is extremely short, perhaps caused by an event such as a network packet collision or a spike in a hardware component.

trans-unit.source: In this case, retrying the operation immediately is appropriate because it may succeed if the fault has cleared in the time it takes the application to assemble and send the next request.
trans-unit.target: In this case, retrying the operation immediately is appropriate because it may succeed if the fault has cleared in the time it takes the application to assemble and send the next request.

trans-unit.source: However, there should never be more than one immediate retry attempt, and you should switch to alternative strategies, such as such as exponential back-off or fallback actions, if the immediate retry fails.
trans-unit.target: However, there should never be more than one immediate retry attempt, and you should switch to alternative strategies, such as such as exponential back-off or fallback actions, if the immediate retry fails.

trans-unit.source: Randomization.
trans-unit.target: Randomization.

trans-unit.source: Any of the retry strategies listed above may include a randomization to prevent multiple instances of the client sending subsequent retry attempts at the same time.
trans-unit.target: Any of the retry strategies listed above may include a randomization to prevent multiple instances of the client sending subsequent retry attempts at the same time.

trans-unit.source: For example, one instance may retry the operation after 3 seconds, 11 seconds, 28 seconds, and so on while another instance may retry the operation after 4 seconds, 12 seconds, 26 seconds, and so on.
trans-unit.target: For example, one instance may retry the operation after 3 seconds, 11 seconds, 28 seconds, and so on while another instance may retry the operation after 4 seconds, 12 seconds, 26 seconds, and so on.

trans-unit.source: Randomization is a useful technique that may be combined with other strategies.
trans-unit.target: Randomization is a useful technique that may be combined with other strategies.

trans-unit.source: As a general guideline, use an exponential back-off strategy for background operations, and immediate or regular interval retry strategies for interactive operations.
trans-unit.target: As a general guideline, use an exponential back-off strategy for background operations, and immediate or regular interval retry strategies for interactive operations.

trans-unit.source: In both cases, you should choose the delay and the retry count so that the maximum latency for all retry attempts is within the required end-to-end latency requirement.
trans-unit.target: In both cases, you should choose the delay and the retry count so that the maximum latency for all retry attempts is within the required end-to-end latency requirement.

trans-unit.source: Take into account the combination of all the factors that contribute to the overall maximum timeout for a retried operation.
trans-unit.target: Take into account the combination of all the factors that contribute to the overall maximum timeout for a retried operation.

trans-unit.source: These factors include the time taken for a failed connection to produce a response (typically set by a timeout value in the client) as well as the delay between retry attempts and the maximum number of retries.
trans-unit.target: These factors include the time taken for a failed connection to produce a response (typically set by a timeout value in the client) as well as the delay between retry attempts and the maximum number of retries.

trans-unit.source: The total of all these times can result in very large overall operation times, especially when using an exponential delay strategy where the interval between retries grows rapidly after each failure.
trans-unit.target: The total of all these times can result in very large overall operation times, especially when using an exponential delay strategy where the interval between retries grows rapidly after each failure.

trans-unit.source: If a process must meet a specific service level agreement (SLA), the overall operation time, including all timeouts and delays, must be within that defined in the SLA
trans-unit.target: If a process must meet a specific service level agreement (SLA), the overall operation time, including all timeouts and delays, must be within that defined in the SLA

trans-unit.source: Over-aggressive retry strategies, which have too short intervals or too may retries, can have an adverse effect on the target resource or service.
trans-unit.target: Over-aggressive retry strategies, which have too short intervals or too may retries, can have an adverse effect on the target resource or service.

trans-unit.source: This may prevent the resource or service from recovering from its overloaded state, and it will continue to block or refuse requests.
trans-unit.target: This may prevent the resource or service from recovering from its overloaded state, and it will continue to block or refuse requests.

trans-unit.source: This results in a vicious circle where more and more requests are sent to the resource or service, and consequently its ability to recover is further reduced.
trans-unit.target: This results in a vicious circle where more and more requests are sent to the resource or service, and consequently its ability to recover is further reduced.

trans-unit.source: Take into account the timeout of the operations when choosing the retry intervals to avoid launching a subsequent attempt immediately (for example, if the timeout period is similar to the retry interval).
trans-unit.target: Take into account the timeout of the operations when choosing the retry intervals to avoid launching a subsequent attempt immediately (for example, if the timeout period is similar to the retry interval).

trans-unit.source: Also consider if you need to keep the total possible period (the timeout plus the retry intervals) to below a specific total time.
trans-unit.target: Also consider if you need to keep the total possible period (the timeout plus the retry intervals) to below a specific total time.

trans-unit.source: Operations that have unusually short or very long timeouts may influence how long to wait, and how often to retry the operation.
trans-unit.target: Operations that have unusually short or very long timeouts may influence how long to wait, and how often to retry the operation.

trans-unit.source: Use the type of the exception and any data it contains, or the error codes and messages returned from the service, to optimize the interval and the number of retries.
trans-unit.target: Use the type of the exception and any data it contains, or the error codes and messages returned from the service, to optimize the interval and the number of retries.

trans-unit.source: For example, some exceptions or error codes (such as the HTTP code 503 Service Unavailable with a Retry-After header in the response) may indicate how long the error might last, or that the service has failed and will not respond to any subsequent attempt.
trans-unit.target: For example, some exceptions or error codes (such as the HTTP code 503 Service Unavailable with a Retry-After header in the response) may indicate how long the error might last, or that the service has failed and will not respond to any subsequent attempt.

trans-unit.source: Avoid anti-patterns:
trans-unit.target: Avoid anti-patterns:

trans-unit.source: In the vast majority of cases, you should avoid implementations that include duplicated layers of retry code.
trans-unit.target: In the vast majority of cases, you should avoid implementations that include duplicated layers of retry code.

trans-unit.source: Avoid designs that include cascading retry mechanisms, or that implement retry at every stage of an operation that involves a hierarchy of requests, unless you have specific requirements that demand this.
trans-unit.target: Avoid designs that include cascading retry mechanisms, or that implement retry at every stage of an operation that involves a hierarchy of requests, unless you have specific requirements that demand this.

trans-unit.source: In these exceptional circumstances, use policies that prevent excessive numbers of retries and delay periods, and make sure you understand the consequences.
trans-unit.target: In these exceptional circumstances, use policies that prevent excessive numbers of retries and delay periods, and make sure you understand the consequences.

trans-unit.source: For example, if one component makes a request to another, which then accesses the target service, and you implement retry with a count of three on both calls there will be nine retry attempts in total against the service.
trans-unit.target: For example, if one component makes a request to another, which then accesses the target service, and you implement retry with a count of three on both calls there will be nine retry attempts in total against the service.

trans-unit.source: Many services and resources implement a built-in retry mechanism and you should investigate how you can disable or modify this if you need to implement retries at a higher level.
trans-unit.target: Many services and resources implement a built-in retry mechanism and you should investigate how you can disable or modify this if you need to implement retries at a higher level.

trans-unit.source: Never implement an endless retry mechanism.
trans-unit.target: Never implement an endless retry mechanism.

trans-unit.source: This is likely to prevent the resource or service recovering from overload situations, and cause throttling and refused connections to continue for a longer period.
trans-unit.target: This is likely to prevent the resource or service recovering from overload situations, and cause throttling and refused connections to continue for a longer period.

trans-unit.source: Use a finite number or retries, or implement a pattern such as <link><linkText>Circuit Breaker</linkText><title></title></link> to allow the service to recover.
trans-unit.target: Use a finite number or retries, or implement a pattern such as <link><linkText>Circuit Breaker</linkText><title></title></link> to allow the service to recover.

trans-unit.source: Never perform an immediate retry more than once.
trans-unit.target: Never perform an immediate retry more than once.

trans-unit.source: Avoid using a regular retry interval, especially when you have a large number of retry attempts, when accessing services and resources in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Avoid using a regular retry interval, especially when you have a large number of retry attempts, when accessing services and resources in Azure.

trans-unit.source: The optimum approach is this scenario is an exponential back-off strategy with a circuit-breaking capability.

trans-unit.source: Manage retry policy configurations:
trans-unit.target: Manage retry policy configurations:

trans-unit.source: A _retry policy_ is a combination of all of the elements of your retry strategy.
trans-unit.target: A _retry policy_ is a combination of all of the elements of your retry strategy.

trans-unit.source: It defines the detection mechanism that determines whether a fault is likely to be transient, the type of interval to use (such as regular, exponential back-off, and randomization), the actual interval value(s), and the number of times to retry.
trans-unit.target: It defines the detection mechanism that determines whether a fault is likely to be transient, the type of interval to use (such as regular, exponential back-off, and randomization), the actual interval value(s), and the number of times to retry.

trans-unit.source: Retries must be implemented in many places within even the simplest application, and in every layer of more complex applications.
trans-unit.target: Retries must be implemented in many places within even the simplest application, and in every layer of more complex applications.

trans-unit.source: Rather than hard-coding the elements of each policy at multiple locations, consider using a central point for storing all the policies.
trans-unit.target: Rather than hard-coding the elements of each policy at multiple locations, consider using a central point for storing all the policies.

trans-unit.source: For example, store the values such as the interval and retry count in application configuration files, read them at runtime, and programmatically build the retry policies.
trans-unit.target: For example, store the values such as the interval and retry count in application configuration files, read them at runtime, and programmatically build the retry policies.

trans-unit.source: This makes it easier to manage the settings, and to modify and fine tune the values in order to respond to changing requirements and scenarios.
trans-unit.target: This makes it easier to manage the settings, and to modify and fine tune the values in order to respond to changing requirements and scenarios.

trans-unit.source: However, design the system to store the values rather than rereading a configuration file every time, and ensure suitable defaults are used if the values cannot be obtained from configuration.
trans-unit.target: However, design the system to store the values rather than rereading a configuration file every time, and ensure suitable defaults are used if the values cannot be obtained from configuration.

trans-unit.source: In an Azure Cloud Services application, consider storing the values that are used to build the retry policies at runtime in the service configuration file so that they can be changed without needing to restart the application.
trans-unit.target: In an Azure Cloud Services application, consider storing the values that are used to build the retry policies at runtime in the service configuration file so that they can be changed without needing to restart the application.

trans-unit.source: Take advantage of built-in or default retry strategies available in the client APIs you use, but only where they are appropriate for your scenario.
trans-unit.target: Take advantage of built-in or default retry strategies available in the client APIs you use, but only where they are appropriate for your scenario.

trans-unit.target: These strategies are typically general-purpose.

trans-unit.source: Log and track transient and non-transient faults:
trans-unit.target: Log and track transient and non-transient faults:

trans-unit.source: As part of your retry strategy, include exception handling and other instrumentation that logs when retry attempts are made.
trans-unit.target: As part of your retry strategy, include exception handling and other instrumentation that logs when retry attempts are made.

trans-unit.source: While an occasional transient failure and retry are to be expected, and do not indicate a problem, regular and increasing numbers of retries are often an indicator of an issue that may cause a failure, or is currently impacting application performance and availability.
trans-unit.target: While an occasional transient failure and retry are to be expected, and do not indicate a problem, regular and increasing numbers of retries are often an indicator of an issue that may cause a failure, or is currently impacting application performance and availability.

trans-unit.source: Log transient faults as Warning entries rather than Error entries so that monitoring systems do not detect them as application errors that may trigger false alerts.
trans-unit.target: Log transient faults as Warning entries rather than Error entries so that monitoring systems do not detect them as application errors that may trigger false alerts.

trans-unit.source: Consider storing a value in your log entries that indicates if the retries were caused by throttling in the service, or by other types of faults such as connection failures, so that you can differentiate them during analysis of the data.
trans-unit.target: Consider storing a value in your log entries that indicates if the retries were caused by throttling in the service, or by other types of faults such as connection failures, so that you can differentiate them during analysis of the data.

trans-unit.source: An increase in the number of throttling errors is often an indicator of a design flaw in the application or the need to switch to a premium service that offers dedicated hardware.
trans-unit.target: An increase in the number of throttling errors is often an indicator of a design flaw in the application or the need to switch to a premium service that offers dedicated hardware.

trans-unit.source: Consider measuring and logging the overall time taken for operations that include a retry mechanism.
trans-unit.target: Consider measuring and logging the overall time taken for operations that include a retry mechanism.

trans-unit.source: This is a good indicator of the overall effect of transient faults on user response times, process latency, and the efficiency of the application use cases.
trans-unit.target: This is a good indicator of the overall effect of transient faults on user response times, process latency, and the efficiency of the application use cases.

trans-unit.source: Also log the number of retries occurred in order to understand the factors that contributed to the response time.
trans-unit.target: Also log the number of retries occurred in order to understand the factors that contributed to the response time.

trans-unit.source: Consider implementing a telemetry and monitoring system that can raise alerts when the number and rate of failures, the average number of retries, or the overall times taken for operations to succeed, is increasing.
trans-unit.target: Consider implementing a telemetry and monitoring system that can raise alerts when the number and rate of failures, the average number of retries, or the overall times taken for operations to succeed, is increasing.

trans-unit.source: Manage operations that continually fail:
trans-unit.target: Manage operations that continually fail:

trans-unit.source: There will be circumstances where the operation continues to fail at every attempt, and it is vital to consider how you will handle this situation:
trans-unit.target: There will be circumstances where the operation continues to fail at every attempt, and it is vital to consider how you will handle this situation:

trans-unit.source: Although a retry strategy will define the maximum number of times that an operation should be retried, it does not prevent the application repeating the operation again, with the same number of retries.
trans-unit.target: Although a retry strategy will define the maximum number of times that an operation should be retried, it does not prevent the application repeating the operation again, with the same number of retries.

trans-unit.source: For example, if an order processing service fails with a fatal error that puts it out of action permanently, the retry strategy may detect a connection timeout and consider it to be a transient fault.
trans-unit.target: For example, if an order processing service fails with a fatal error that puts it out of action permanently, the retry strategy may detect a connection timeout and consider it to be a transient fault.

trans-unit.source: The code will retry the operation a specified number of times and then give up.
trans-unit.target: The code will retry the operation a specified number of times and then give up.

trans-unit.source: However, when another customer places an order, the operation will be attempted again - even though it is sure to fail every time.
trans-unit.target: However, when another customer places an order, the operation will be attempted again - even though it is sure to fail every time.

trans-unit.source: To prevent continual retries for operations that continually fail, consider implementing the <link><linkText>Circuit Breaker pattern</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: To prevent continual retries for operations that continually fail, consider implementing the <link><linkText>Circuit Breaker pattern</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: In this pattern, if the number of failures within a specified time window exceeds the threshold, requests are returned to the caller immediately as errors, without attempting to access the failed resource or service.
trans-unit.target: In this pattern, if the number of failures within a specified time window exceeds the threshold, requests are returned to the caller immediately as errors, without attempting to access the failed resource or service.

trans-unit.source: Other considerations
trans-unit.target: Other considerations

trans-unit.source: When deciding on the values for the number of retries and the retry intervals for a policy, consider if the operation on the service or resource is part of a long-running or multi-step operation.
trans-unit.target: When deciding on the values for the number of retries and the retry intervals for a policy, consider if the operation on the service or resource is part of a long-running or multi-step operation.

trans-unit.source: It may be difficult or expensive to compensate all the other operational steps that have already succeeded when one fails.
trans-unit.target: It may be difficult or expensive to compensate all the other operational steps that have already succeeded when one fails.

trans-unit.source: In this case, a very long interval and a large number of retries may be acceptable as long as it does not block other operations by holding or locking scarce resources.
trans-unit.target: In this case, a very long interval and a large number of retries may be acceptable as long as it does not block other operations by holding or locking scarce resources.

trans-unit.source: Consider if retrying the same operation may cause inconsistencies in data.
trans-unit.target: Consider if retrying the same operation may cause inconsistencies in data.

trans-unit.source: If some parts of a multi-step process are repeated, and the operations are not idempotent, it may result in an inconsistency.
trans-unit.target: If some parts of a multi-step process are repeated, and the operations are not idempotent, it may result in an inconsistency.

trans-unit.source: For example, an operation that increments a value, if repeated, will produce an invalid result.
trans-unit.target: For example, an operation that increments a value, if repeated, will produce an invalid result.

trans-unit.source: Repeating an operation that sends a message to a queue may cause an inconsistency in the message consumer if it cannot detect duplicate messages.
trans-unit.target: Repeating an operation that sends a message to a queue may cause an inconsistency in the message consumer if it cannot detect duplicate messages.

trans-unit.source: To prevent this, ensure that you design each step as an idempotent operation.
trans-unit.target: To prevent this, ensure that you design each step as an idempotent operation.

trans-unit.source: For more information about idempotency, see <link><linkText>Idempotence Patterns</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about idempotency, see <link><linkText>Idempotence Patterns</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Consider the scope of the operations that will be retried.
trans-unit.target: Consider the scope of the operations that will be retried.

trans-unit.source: For example, it may be easier to implement retry code at a level that encompasses several operations, and retry them all if one fails.
trans-unit.target: For example, it may be easier to implement retry code at a level that encompasses several operations, and retry them all if one fails.

trans-unit.source: However, doing this may result in idempotency issues or unnecessary rollback operations.
trans-unit.target: However, doing this may result in idempotency issues or unnecessary rollback operations.

trans-unit.source: If you choose a retry scope that encompasses several operations, take into account the total latency of all of them when determining the retry intervals, when monitoring the time taken, and before raising alerts for failures.
trans-unit.target: If you choose a retry scope that encompasses several operations, take into account the total latency of all of them when determining the retry intervals, when monitoring the time taken, and before raising alerts for failures.

trans-unit.source: Consider how your retry strategy may affect neighbors and other tenants in a shared application, or when using shared resources and services.
trans-unit.target: Consider how your retry strategy may affect neighbors and other tenants in a shared application, or when using shared resources and services.
